sentences: Auguste Mathieu Panseron (26 April 1796 – 29 July 1859) was a French composer and voice teacher.
Born in Paris, Panseron studied in Vienna with Antonio Salieri, having been accepted by the master thanks to a recommendation by Luigi Cherubini.
In 1824, Panseron began teaching singing at the Conservatoire de Paris.
Early in his career, he wrote four works for the Opéra-Comique in Paris:
La Grille du parc (1820),  Les Deux cousines (1821), Le Mariage difficile (1823), and L'École de Rome (1829).
Panseron gained a lasting reputation with his pedagogical works, many of which continue to be published and used today.
